name: Bergen
fun_fact: Fun fact: Bergen was Europe's largest wooden city in the 19th century and is the site of Norway's most profound unsolved mystery - the Isdal Woman case from 1970, where an unidentified woman was found dead with fake passports and encrypted notes

hero_dishes.name: Fiskesuppe (Bergen Fish Soup)
hero_dishes.description: A rich, creamy soup loaded with chunks of fresh cod, salmon, and shellfish, swimming in a white wine-spiked broth with carrots and leeks
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born from Bergen's 900-year history as Norway's seafood capital and historic Hanseatic trading port. The fish market has operated continuously since the 1200s, and this soup represents the city's maritime soul
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bryggeloftet & Stuene at Bryggen 11 (their signature dish), Bergen Fish Market waterfront stalls

hero_dishes.name: Raspeballer (Komle)
hero_dishes.description: Massive potato dumplings the size of softballs, traditionally served with salted pork belly, crispy bacon bits, and mashed rutabaga
hero_dishes.origin_story: A working-class staple from Bergen's fishing and trading era - designed to fuel dock workers through 12-hour shifts in the rain. The name 'komle' comes from the round, compact shape
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Pingvinen (the laid-back pub serving generous portions), Bryggen Tracteursted

hero_dishes.name: Fiskegrateng
hero_dishes.description: Baked fish gratin with macaroni, topped with golden breadcrumbs and melted cheese - Norwegian comfort food at its finest
hero_dishes.origin_story: A post-war dish that became a Bergen household staple, combining abundant local fish with imported pasta. Every Bergen grandmother has her own secret recipe
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Pingvinen (known for authentic home-style Norwegian cooking), local cafes throughout Bryggen district

hero_dishes.name: Gin-Cured Reindeer
hero_dishes.description: Paper-thin slices of wild reindeer, cured with Norwegian gin and juniper berries, served with cloudberry jam and crispy flatbread
hero_dishes.origin_story: A modern New Nordic interpretation of ancient Sami preservation techniques, now a signature dish at Bergen's Michelin-starred restaurants
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Lysverket (one Michelin star, inside KODE 4 art museum), Gaptrast (newly Michelin-starred)

signature_drinks.name: Akevitt (Norwegian Aquavit)
signature_drinks.description: Caraway and dill-flavored spirit aged in oak barrels, traditionally served ice-cold in small glasses
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Always chilled, never sipped slowly - knock it back in one go with seafood or fatty pork dishes. Bergen locals prefer Linie Aquavit, which crosses the equator twice in oak barrels on cargo ships

signature_drinks.name: Bergen Craft Beer
signature_drinks.description: Local microbrews from Bergen's booming craft scene, often incorporating Norwegian ingredients like spruce tips and sea buckthorn
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed at cozy pubs to escape the rain - Bergen gets 231 rainy days per year. Pair with fiskeballer (fish balls) at Pingvinen or any traditional pub

food_culture_notes: Bergen's Fish Market has operated continuously for over 800 years - locals still shop there daily for dinner
The Hanseatic influence means German surnames (Friele, Mowinckel) still appear on restaurant signs and coffee roasters
Whale carpaccio appears on menus at traditional spots like Pingvinen - controversial but historically eaten in Norway
New Nordic cuisine dominates fine dining, with Michelin restaurants like Lysverket and Gaptrast showcasing hyper-local ingredients
